[h2]Short Summary[/h2]
A systems-heavy idle game that excels at deep, interconnected progression. It provides a massive optimization puzzle for players who love managing complex trees, tasks, and resources.

[h2]The Takeaway[/h2]
[list]
[*] [h3]Bright Spots / What Works[/h3] The core appeal is juggling dozens of 'Actions' (like jobs and training) with talent trees and interconnected systems like crafting, property, and spell management.
[*] [h3]Major Drawbacks / What Might Not Suit You[/h3] The gameplay loop can become repetitive. Progress may feel heavily gated, slowing significantly without very active, strategic management.
[*] [h3]What It's About[/h3] The patient, unending pursuit of ultimate magical knowledge and learning to manage the growing power and integrated systems.
[*] [h3]How It Plays[/h3] A pure, numbers-driven progression system that directly tests your ability to optimize and manage resources.
[*] [h3]Core Tone[/h3] Contemplative and methodical. The atmosphere is mystical but humorous, focused entirely on slow-burn growth.
[*] [h3]Series & Genre Context[/h3] A standout in the "complex idle" subgenre. It is built for players who prefer interconnected numbers-go-up systems over action or narrative.
[*] [h3]Technical Snapshot[/h3] Very stable with a dense but functional UI. Tooltips are essential and generally clear. It's well-optimized for long-running background sessions.
[/list]
[h2]Main Review[/h2]
[b]Idle Awakening: Mages Path[/b] casts you as an overseer. You are not a hero in the field but the high-level guide for a mage's development. This is a game about the patient, unending pursuit of ultimate magical knowledge. Your role is to manage the burden of that immense power by making smart, strategic decisions from afar.

The gameplay is a masterclass in interconnected systems. Your primary task is to juggle a vast array of 'Actions', such as jobs and training, to build core attributes. These stats, in turn, unlock nodes in a multi-layered talent trees. This entire loop feeds a series of other deep systems. You will manage crafting in the Workshop, optimize spell rotations in the Magic tab, and develop properties and build furniture and accessories. It is a pure, numbers-driven progression puzzle designed to test your optimization and resource management skills - or relax and wait for progression.

This intricate mechanical focus creates a contemplative and methodical tone. The game feels mystical and arcane, capturing the feeling of slow-burn growth and academic study. There is no urgent threat. The narrative is minimalist, with any story beats serving only as milestones to mark your next level of progression. The world is not a place you explore, but a set of systems you master.

[b]Idle Awakening: Mages Path[/b] is a triumphant example of the "optimizer's" idle game. It wastes no time on story or action. Instead, it dedicates all its resources to building a deep, complex, and satisfying engine for players to tinker with.

[h2]The Verdict[/h2]
This game is for the systems-driven strategist. It is a perfect fit for players who love spreadsheets, theorycrafting, and managing dozens of interlocking mechanics. If you want a game to run in the background while you optimize complex builds, this is ideal. Those who need a strong narrative or active gameplay will find nothing here. The loop can become repetitive, and progress will feel gated if you are not actively managing your strategy.

[i]For the patient optimizer who finds joy in pure, numbers-driven progression, this is a highly recommended experience.[/i]

The primary gameplay is to create list of activities that your character will perform, splitting your time among different tasks to balance resource costs / recovery rates.   For example, you might work a job that costs health and energy but provides coins, spend the coins on books to read to generate knowledge, and spend the knowledge on an activity to train up your learning rate.   You balance the % of these tasks within the list so you don't run out of resources, and then run it.   Then you'll make a list for some other goal, and so on.   This automation unlocks pretty fast, within the first couple hours of the game.  

The pacing of new resources and mechanics is quite smooth.  You'll unlock several things in the first day and then youll keep unlocking a new mechanic to play with every day or two after that.  

While most similar to Arcanum, it also kind of feels like a more idle version of Orb of Creation to me.  No resets, constant progress through new mechanics, but instead of actively casting spells, here you are creating and managing automation lists.

If you'd like an idle game without a prestige/restart mechanic that offers continuous progress and development, this is the game for you. There's a lot of automation built in so you can make the most of your online and offline time.

Reminds me of Immortality Idle, a free fun but shallow little game that filled a niche. There's a lot of the same systems that I love. It definitely needs a lot of work, but I love the game concept. Currently there's a few glaring issues with progression that are causing problems, and I want to discuss them and offer solutions to the developer. This is one of my favourite kind of niches that I can't even put into words. So I hope this turns into something amazing.

One of the issues is the skill tree. As another player has pointed out, tying specific skill learning increases to it forces players to respec into specialised builds from mid to late game. This negates the whole point of having choices in it, but it also just feels bad in general. If you have to respec and do one kind of activity only, for a game built on switching between a variety of activities, you've introduced a mechanic directly clashing with your core design. To me the easiest fix is to redesign the skill tree to give generalised increases such as Learning Rate and a general XP Discount. Remove the coins, mana, health, energy etc. increases entirely. Keep those in the other permanent systems that you get as you progress. Then in-between the general increases, place in some special nodes for people to aim toward (such as unlocking special activities, items, property etc.) and remove respeccing entirely. It should feel to the player like they're getting something that adds to what they're already doing, not having it decide on what they have to do.

Diversity of choice/discovery is another issue. Currently there is zero in this game, and this is caused by the lack of encounters. I hope this is something the developer focuses on over time. Too much of the mid to late game is tied to the progression of attributes. Almost every "you reached x in an action" moment is exposition with no impact on the game. This kind of game is centred around discovery, and if there's no expectation of discovery you have a severe issue. The player needs a variety of encounters (discovery) to fuel their excitement and go for that "just one more milestone" feeling. I recommend to slowly fill out a percentage of those action encounters with an impact on the game. It makes the world feel alive. It can be small or large, such as unlocking temporary or permanent action, adding a variety of permanent buffs, unlocking items, property, magic etc. I'd also have hidden threshold encounters, where having reached certain milestones (such as x learning speed or x property size or x furniture etc.) unlocks something new. I'd also have random encounters, that is encounters that can happen at random (you can even include encoutners based on player progress) that offer something temporary, like a resource or speed increase, or even hints on how to unlock certain things. You can have repeat encounters for temporary buffs, and once-only encounters that do something special. There are more options, but just those three types of encounters will add a lot of depth to the game's discovery.

The last major issue to me is tied to the above as well, with a lack of progression divergence. Currently too many parts of the progression is linear. For example, Magic offers only 7 spells at the start that you all unlock basically at the same time. These do a variety of buffs that end up being "for x action maintain y spell". There are no choices here. No decisions to make. You either turn one of the 7 spells on or off based on which action you are doing. Too much of the game is like this. You need to give players decisions to make at various stages of the game. It's what gives players agency, and agency is what invests them into your game. This one's more complex and I'm a bit too tired to think of suggestions, but I might come back to it later.

There's different playstyle as you're free to prioritize or equally improve several categories of abilities (physical, social, magic, mental) and there's a nice amount of things to do with ressource crafting, herb gathering, alchemy and spell casting. All with their layer of optional automation. (There's a lot of cross-category synergies btw, don't entirely ignore any one of them)

It's still in Early Access, but I'm satisfied with the amount of content and polish. The dev is actively working on it and listens to feedback.

[h2]Short Summary[/h2]
A systems-heavy idle game that excels at deep, interconnected progression. It provides a massive optimization puzzle for players who love managing complex trees, tasks, and resources.

[h2]The Takeaway[/h2]
[list]
[*] [h3]Bright Spots / What Works[/h3] The core appeal is juggling dozens of 'Actions' (like jobs and training) with talent trees and interconnected systems like crafting, property, and spell management.
[*] [h3]Major Drawbacks / What Might Not Suit You[/h3] The gameplay loop can become repetitive. Progress may feel heavily gated, slowing significantly without very active, strategic management.
[*] [h3]What It's About[/h3] The patient, unending pursuit of ultimate magical knowledge and learning to manage the growing power and integrated systems.
[*] [h3]How It Plays[/h3] A pure, numbers-driven progression system that directly tests your ability to optimize and manage resources.
[*] [h3]Core Tone[/h3] Contemplative and methodical. The atmosphere is mystical but humorous, focused entirely on slow-burn growth.
[*] [h3]Series & Genre Context[/h3] A standout in the "complex idle" subgenre. It is built for players who prefer interconnected numbers-go-up systems over action or narrative.
[*] [h3]Technical Snapshot[/h3] Very stable with a dense but functional UI. Tooltips are essential and generally clear. It's well-optimized for long-running background sessions.
[/list]
[h2]Main Review[/h2]
[b]Idle Awakening: Mages Path[/b] casts you as an overseer. You are not a hero in the field but the high-level guide for a mage's development. This is a game about the patient, unending pursuit of ultimate magical knowledge. Your role is to manage the burden of that immense power by making smart, strategic decisions from afar.

The gameplay is a masterclass in interconnected systems. Your primary task is to juggle a vast array of 'Actions', such as jobs and training, to build core attributes. These stats, in turn, unlock nodes in a multi-layered talent trees. This entire loop feeds a series of other deep systems. You will manage crafting in the Workshop, optimize spell rotations in the Magic tab, and develop properties and build furniture and accessories. It is a pure, numbers-driven progression puzzle designed to test your optimization and resource management skills - or relax and wait for progression.

This intricate mechanical focus creates a contemplative and methodical tone. The game feels mystical and arcane, capturing the feeling of slow-burn growth and academic study. There is no urgent threat. The narrative is minimalist, with any story beats serving only as milestones to mark your next level of progression. The world is not a place you explore, but a set of systems you master.

[b]Idle Awakening: Mages Path[/b] is a triumphant example of the "optimizer's" idle game. It wastes no time on story or action. Instead, it dedicates all its resources to building a deep, complex, and satisfying engine for players to tinker with.

[h2]The Verdict[/h2]
This game is for the systems-driven strategist. It is a perfect fit for players who love spreadsheets, theorycrafting, and managing dozens of interlocking mechanics. If you want a game to run in the background while you optimize complex builds, this is ideal. Those who need a strong narrative or active gameplay will find nothing here. The loop can become repetitive, and progress will feel gated if you are not actively managing your strategy.

[i]For the patient optimizer who finds joy in pure, numbers-driven progression, this is a highly recommended experience.[/i]

In more detail,
the good: 
1. Clean UI. 
2. Lots of mechanics. 
3. Well thought out progression.
4. Good writing, (A side-note here, the way of writing is good, but the story itself, constantly reminding you that your character is an absolute idiot, even after 10 hours in the game, is getting repetitive)
the bad: 
1. Steep decline of progress 10 hours in. 
2a. The potion to reset your skills requires an insane amount of materials.
2b. No prestige. This would have been a great alternative to reseting your skills. Don't like the build you have? Start anew. I for one really like the prestige element of other idles, but since the dev has this as a selling point on the steam page, I won't say anything more on the matter.
3. My biggest issue with this game is that the way you unlock new mechanics is kind of hidden. For example, you have the ability to walk from the start of the game. The UI tells you that "Every 100 levels of this action, it ranks up giving you bigger benefits." And every now and then when you hit a level like 10,25,50,75 or 100 you might get some more story and unlock new things. The problem is that you have no idea at what level you might unlock a new thing and how much easier this new thing might make the game. Let's say you hit level 10 and you unlock the ability to buy new shoes, which give you more exp per second for your walking ability while walking. So you spend 10 minutes making money to buy those shoes and go back to walking. Then on level 25 of walking, you unlock a new job that gives you more money than the previous one, so you start wondering if it would have been better to keep walking to level 25 and just go and do the next job after that. (I don't remember exactly what you unlock on each level, just making an example here)

This way of unlocking new things is annoying (at least to me). I find myself thinking "Should I put a few more levels on that skill or will it be a waste of time?" most of the time playing this game.
A suggestion for this issue: This could easily be offset with a new spell that tells you which skill requires the least amount of leveling up for the next unlock.

All in all, I am excited to see more from this game, but I think I will wait a few more months before coming back to it.

It felt like a great addition to the "Life-sim" type of idle game, and had a similar feel to Orb of Creation, one of the best incremental games out there, that being a feeling of steady progress and building depth where you can either choose to let growth happen in the background or play actively for faster completion. I really did enjoy it! Played for 3 or so hours. Then I bought the game...

And noticed the opening splash. The wizard holding the book has ridiculously long fingers. Then I looked at the items you buy from the store. Then I looked at the background. It's AI "art" This was rather distressing. If you are not aware of why this might be problematic, let me give my understanding of the problems with these AI processes. 

For one, the actual cost of these AI services is astronomical. They require huge server arrays that demand massive amounts of power, water for cooling, space, and rare minerals for the graphics cards. These facilities are often built by massive companies in remote areas due to the high environmental cost, need for water access, and the noise produced. The nearby towns are then either literally torn down or rendered nearly uninhabitable due to the waste and extreme energy price spikes.

Then, before we've even gotten to the crappy picture, the data used to create the image is all stolen. I'm sure whoever is reading this has heard this before, but it's probably worse than you may know. The AI companies are, nowadays, the biggest purchasers of private data. They send out bots across the entire internet, and when I say the entire internet, I mean potentially thousands of computers dedicated to sending out these scrapers. These bots slow down the websites for us human users, steal data from every single inch of the website including but not limited to comments, images, videos, games, and screenshots. It doesn't matter who you are, they will take it. This of course leads to artists of every caliber, popular or unknown, great or terrible, images or text, stolen. The data is scraped, sent to the massive and expensive facilities (that I must reemphasize are driving up energy costs for everybody, especially those near one), and used to train their flavor of AI.

What, then, is the result of all of this theft and destruction? You get an uncanny valley picture of a really colorful person with weird fingers making odd expressions. You get oddities like lettuce with weird bulges and inexplicable asymmetry. You get regurgitated computer data built on the stolen work of real people at great environmental and human cost, as well as cheapening the game itself. And there really is no excuse. You can spend $40, or the equivalent in whatever currency, to buy an asset pack from any number of online stores and get a greater level of quality and consistency. It might be cheaper, or even free, if you get a bit lucky. Look at Orb of Creation for an example of an incredibly well used asset pack.

As it is, I commend the Dev on the excellent game they have made (at least as far as the demo goes), but refuse to play this game so long as the art's integrity is so severely compromised for so little reason. I cannot give you money in good conscience.

The only magical thing you do is click on some spells to autocast. It doesn't feel like magic. It feels like you're a crazy man building an estate by himself out of untamed wilderness, and one of your options happens to be themed as spells.
